author: potuz
content: I was about to post something along these lines, I take that tweet perhaps as a form of advertisement. There are other consensus mechanisms that have proofs and are not practical for a network like Ethereum, and now there's a proposal (Goldfish) which is joint work of members of his team and the EF that is designed to be applicable to Ethereum

author: fradamt
content: That‚Äôs one part of the problem, the other one is that we don‚Äôt run LMD-GHOST but committee-LMD-GHOST, and that we use proposer boost instead of view-merge. LMD-GHOST without committees and with view-merge has great properties under full participation, and I think one can easily modify it with vote expiry to satisfy some practically sufficient definition of dynamically availability (though maybe not the standard one). Good thing is, this means that, if we can get everyone voting in one slot, at least this part of our problems is solved

author: fradamt
content: Since there has been a lot of confusion about this, let me just clarify what Goldfish is and what it is not. It is a protocol which satisfies reorg-resilience, dynamic availability and accountable safety with optimal adversarial resilience and can give fast confirmations , all properties we want, and *the available component* is very easily applicable to Ethereum. That said, the latter is ‚Äútoo synchronous‚Äù in a way in which LMD-GHOST is not (the tradeoff being that it allows for committees, which LMD-GHOST doesn‚Äôt really do, as mentioned in the previous message). For that reason, I think it is quite unlikely it would actually be considered  for use on Ethereum (unless we start seeing a lot of short ex-ante reorgs by very large staking pools and really need a fast response, which doesn‚Äôt seem realistic). Moreover, while it combines available chain and finality gadget securely, that part is not as easily applicable to Ethereum.

author: jgm
content: When you say "get everyone voting in one slot", do you mean that everyone votes in every slot?  That would result in a very high amount of network traffic under current conditions.

author: sproul
content: Yeah AFAIK this is required for single slot finality, and would require efficient aggregation at the network level, i.e. everyone on subnets signing _the same_ aggregateable message

author: jgm
content: Doesn't that require everyone on the subnet agreeing on the same message, which would require some sort of consensus system itself?

author: fradamt
content: Not sure if that‚Äôs what he meant, but today each subnet signs a different message even if they agree on the consensus-relevant part of the message, because there is a committee_index field in the message to sign, which is not required. Once that is out of the picture, one strategy could be to have a second layer of aggregation, e.g. 32 larger subnets, each one having 1/32 of the validator set in it, and further aggregating the first layer aggregates. Basically, each top-level subnet would gossip the same messages as today‚Äôs global beacon_aggregate_and_proof topic, roughly 1024 aggregates, and those would be further aggregated before going into global gossip

author: fradamt
content: We are actively working on this atm, and trying to understand what‚Äôs feasible and what‚Äôs not, in terms of networking and other things, e.g. verification times. I think it‚Äôs hard to imagine doing this without increasing slot times by 4-8s, which I guess would be very controversial, but seems very much worth it to me?

author: fradamt
content: with the caveat of higher slot times being potentially much worse if PBS is done and the construction is the 2-slot one, so that we get another 2x longer effective slot times

author: jgm
content:
You could probably take 2s from the current slot time by pushing out the attestation phase to be from 4s to 10s, and the aggregate phase from 10s to 12s, as very little happens in the aggregation time period as far as I have seen.  But increasing slot times significantly is going to be tough (possibly mitigated by increasing the gas limit significantly?)

Subnets also take time to establish, from my understanding, so continually reconfiguring them could be painful.  I don't have any detailed knowledge of the p2p layer though so not sure if that is the case.
